articles.headline: Nevada’s Struggling Economy Is a Wild Card in the Presidential Race
articles.snippet: The state is among a handful that will decide the presidential contest, and workers have felt increased prices at the grocery store and gas station.
articles.abstract: The state is among a handful that will decide the presidential contest, and workers have felt increased prices at the grocery store and gas station.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sold-out shows along the Strip. Crews constructing a course for a major Formula 1 race. A record number of passengers at Harry Reid International Airport.

articles.headline: The Chinese Chipmaker at the Heart of the U.S.-China Tech War
articles.snippet: Efforts by the Beijing-backed Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation, or SMIC, to break through innovation barriers have landed it in a geopolitical tech battle.
articles.abstract: Efforts by the Beijing-backed Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation, or SMIC, to break through innovation barriers have landed it in a geopolitical tech battle.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a sprawling factory in eastern Shanghai, where marshy plains have long since been converted into industrial parks, China’s most advanced chipmaker has been hard at work testing the limits of U.S. authority.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson, John Liu and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: Tim Walz, a ‘Snowman Melting,’ Tests His Appeal in the Sun Belt
articles.snippet: The Minnesota governor was picked for his appeal to the white working-class. The Harris campaign hopes he can reach other demographics, too.
articles.abstract: The Minnesota governor was picked for his appeal to the white working-class. The Harris campaign hopes he can reach other demographics, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Vice President Kamala Harris selected Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota as her running mate, many Democrats hoped that his folksy charm, quick-witted jabs at Republican opponents and “Minnesota nice” values would draw in white, working-class voters from across the Midwest — and potentially beyond.
articles.byline: By Kellen Browning and Jazmine Ulloa

articles.headline: Trump, Outrage and the Modern Era of Political Violence
articles.snippet: The latest apparent assassination attempt against the former president indicates how much the American political landscape has been shaped by anger stirred by him and against him.
articles.abstract: The latest apparent assassination attempt against the former president indicates how much the American political landscape has been shaped by anger stirred by him and against him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Within days of former President Donald J. Trump vilifying immigrants on national television with false stories about Haitian migrants eating pet dogs and cats in an Ohio town, someone began threatening to blow up schools, City Hall and other public buildings, forcing evacuations and prompting a wave of fear.

articles.headline: Judges Show Some Skepticism of TikTok’s Fight Against Potential U.S. Ban
articles.snippet: TikTok on Monday pushed back against a law that would force the popular video app to sell to a non-Chinese owner or be banned, in what is shaping up to be a landmark case.
articles.abstract: TikTok on Monday pushed back against a law that would force the popular video app to sell to a non-Chinese owner or be banned, in what is shaping up to be a landmark case.
articles.lead_paragraph: A panel of federal judges on Monday made pointed remarks that called TikTok’s legal arguments into question, in a landmark case that could determine whether the Chinese-owned video app survives in the country.
articles.byline: By Sapna Maheshwari and David McCabe

articles.headline: China’s ‘Silver Economy’ Is Thriving as Birthrate Plunges
articles.snippet: The shrinking population poses threats to growth but has opened opportunities for businesses that serve seniors.
articles.abstract: The shrinking population poses threats to growth but has opened opportunities for businesses that serve seniors.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, Li Dongmei operated a series of kindergartens and schools for young children, withstanding the realities of China’s declining birthrate. She finally faced the music in 2020.
articles.byline: By Claire Fu and Daisuke Wakabayashi

articles.headline: Will Lower Rates Unleash a Business Boom? It’s Complicated.
articles.snippet: For corporate America, this week’s expected interest rate cut carries risks along with rewards.
articles.abstract: For corporate America, this week’s expected interest rate cut carries risks along with rewards.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s easy to assume that lower interest rates are a panacea. Almost everyone, after all, is affected to some degree by the cost of borrowing. When the Federal Reserve cuts its benchmark rates — as it is expected to do this week for the first time since the pandemic — that makes credit less expensive for consumers and corporations alike. The cheaper debt means companies can spend more to expand, just as consumers might be able to afford bigger homes with lower mortgage rates.
articles.byline: By Rob Copeland, Joe Rennison and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: What the Fed Rate Cut Will Mean for Five Areas of Your Financial Life
articles.snippet: Here’s what the half-point interest rate cut will mean for your car loans, credit cards, mortgages, savings and student loans.
articles.abstract: Here’s what the half-point interest rate cut will mean for your car loans, credit cards, mortgages, savings and student loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: The moment consumers have been waiting for is finally here: The Federal Reserve cut its key interest rate by half a percentage point Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber and Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: Instagram, Facing Pressure Over Child Safety Online, Unveils Sweeping Changes
articles.snippet: The app, which is popular with teenagers, introduced new settings and features aimed at addressing inappropriate online contact and content, and improving sleep for users under 18.
articles.abstract: The app, which is popular with teenagers, introduced new settings and features aimed at addressing inappropriate online contact and content, and improving sleep for users under 18.
articles.lead_paragraph: Instagram unveiled a sweeping overhaul on Tuesday to beef up privacy and limit social media’s intrusive effects for users who are younger than 18, as the app faces intensifying pressure over children’s safety online.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Natasha Singer

articles.headline: Harris Campaign Says She Will Meet the Press (on Her Terms)
articles.snippet: The vice president, who has granted few interviews as the Democratic nominee, is now ramping things up. But she is likely to focus on local outlets and nontraditional venues where voters get their news.
articles.abstract: The vice president, who has granted few interviews as the Democratic nominee, is now ramping things up. But she is likely to focus on local outlets and nontraditional venues where voters get their news.
articles.lead_paragraph: She has hosted a convention, weathered a debate, held her first sit-down interview with a major television network.
articles.byline: By Reid J. Epstein and Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: $50 Billion in Aid to Ukraine Stalls Over Legal Questions
articles.snippet: U.S. and European officials are struggling to honor their pledge to use Russian assets to aid Ukraine.
articles.abstract: U.S. and European officials are struggling to honor their pledge to use Russian assets to aid Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: A long-awaited plan to help Ukraine rebuild using Russian money is in limbo as the United States and Europe struggle to agree on how to construct a $50 billion loan using Russia’s frozen central bank assets while complying with their own laws.

articles.headline: How A.I., QAnon and Falsehoods Are Reshaping the Presidential Race
articles.snippet: Three experts on social media and disinformation share their predictions for this year’s chaotic election.
articles.abstract: Three experts on social media and disinformation share their predictions for this year’s chaotic election.
articles.lead_paragraph: This year’s presidential election has been polluted with rumors, conspiracy theories and a wave of artificial intelligence imagery. Former President Donald J. Trump has continued to sow doubts about election integrity as his allies across the country have taken steps to make election denial a fixture of the balloting process.
